1967-2016 1979-2010 Robert Landy is Professor of Educational Theatre and Applied Psychology at NYU. He founded NYU's Drama Therapy program in 1984, and pioneered the profession of Drama Therapy, treating children and adults with a wide range of psychiatric, cognitive and adjustment challenges This collection consists of materials documenting Landy's intellectual, professional, and theatrical activities. Materials include interviews, lectures, and performances, edited plays, and a documentary, related to Landy's research, writing, and drama therapy practices. This collection also includes video tapes on various formats of NYU's education television series Sunrise Semester. The collection also includes original artwork, interview notes, correspondence, typescripts and manuscripts, permission forms, press releases and publishing materials, photographs and negatives. Materials are mostly in English. Some video materials are in Japanese.
The 2016 accretion also includes materials in the following languages: Greek, Spanish, Korean, Hebrew, Japanese, Arabic, Hindi, Chinese (Taiwan), Czech, German, and Bulgarian.
Conditions Governing Access
Administrative records and unpublished reports of New York University are closed for a period of 20 years from the date of their creation. Access to files spanning multiple years will be opened to researchers based on the date of the most recent materials. Board of Trustees records are closed for 35 years from the date of creation. Materials related to personnel, grievances, job and fellowship searches and applications, and all files that fall under the federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) are permanently restricted. Additional restrictions may apply to other materials in this collection. For questions regarding specific restrictions, please contact the University Archives.
Biographical/Historical Note
Robert Landy is Professor of Educational Theatre and Applied Psychology at NYU. He founded NYU's Drama Therapy program in 1984, and pioneered the profession of Drama Therapy, treating children and adults with a wide range of psychiatric, cognitive and adjustment challenges. He has written numerous books, plays, and articles related to his work with drama therapy, and has also developed programs to treat mentally ill offenders as well as general population in New York State prisons.
Processing Information
At the time of accessioning a collection-level finding aid with a box list was created to describe these materials, retaining the original box label titles. No physical processing or arrangement was performed at this time. Original box label titles were retained. Accretions have been intellectually and physically added to the end of the collection but not otherwise integrated.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Robert Landy Papers; MC 259; box number; folder number; University Archives, New York University
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Robert Landy to the University Archives on December 7, 2015. The accession number associated with this gift is 15.042. Further accretions have been donated in April, August, and December of 2016, as well as May of 2017; the accession numbers associated with these gift are 2016.018, 2016.022, 2016.039, and 2017.013, respectively.
Use Restrictions
Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by the creator are maintained by New York University. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from New York University Archives, (212) 998-2646, university-archives@nyu.edu.
Arrangement Note
This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.
Scope and Contents Note
This collection consists of materials documenting the intellectual and theatrical activities of Robert Landy. Materials include interviews, lectures, and performances, edited plays, and a documentary, related to Landy's research, writing, and drama therapy practices. This collection also includes video tapes on various formats of Sunrise Semester, the early NYU distance learning television series produced by CBS, which ran from 1957-1982. The collection also includes original artwork, interview notes, correspondence, typescripts and manuscripts, permission forms, press releases and publishing materials, photographs and negatives. Much of these materials relate to his books Letters from Sing Sing and How We See God and Why it Matters.
Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact the University Archives with collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
